metadata.title: MnO2 Nanoflowers Deposited on Graphene Paper as Electrode Materials for Supercapacitors

sections.text:
KEYWORDS: electrochemical exfoliation, electrodeposition, graphene paper, green method, MnO2 nanoflowers
■ INTRODUCTION Electrochemical energy-storage devices such as batteries and supercapacitors have unique properties. Among them, supercapacitors (SC) have attracted extensive investigations because of their high power density, quick charge/discharge times, long cycle life (>100 000 cycles), and low cost of fabrication.1−3
However, they suffer from low energy density, which limits their extensive commercial applications.4−6 Much research has been directed at improving the energy density of supercapacitor electrode materials, primarily using carbonaceous composites made of graphene foam/paper, carbon nanotube (CNT) film, and carbon fiber cloth with transition-metal oxides or conjugated polymers.7,8
A wide range of metal oxides (nickel, ruthenium, and manganese oxides, etc.) are used as SC electrode materials.9
Among them, manganese can exist in different valence states (+2, +3, +4). It can form various stable oxides (MnO, Mn3O4, Mn2O3, MnO2) with a variety of electrochemical properties, crystal structures, morphology, porosity, and textures.10 Among
them, MnO2 has the greatest potential because of its stability and different structural forms, α-, β-, γ-, and λ-type, among others.11 MnO2 is also naturally abundant, inexpensive, and environmentally benign.12 However, low electrical conductivity (10−5−10−6 S·cm−1), low cyclic stability, and low rate capacity have limited the applications of MnO2.
13,14 To overcome these limitations, an effective strategy is to combine carbonaceous material with manganese nanostructures.15
Graphene, an outstanding two-dimensional (2D) carbon structure, has attracted strong considerations as a result of its exceptional mechanical, electrical, thermal, and optical properties.16−18 Graphene is also a standout among most materials for flexible and portable devices19 because it can be integrated into flexible, interconnected, and free-standing three-dimensional (3D) networks such as paper,1,20 foam,21 film,22 aerogels,23
Received: April 30, 2019 Accepted: June 11, 2019 Published: June 11, 2019

hydrogels,24 or other substrates.25 Thus, 3D porous graphene structures are suitable platforms to fabricate flexible supercapacitors.26 However, cost-effective and environmentally friendly methods are required to afford large-scale manufacturing of graphene and broaden its applications.27 In this vein, the graphene paper (GrP) we have fabricated is an easy-to-prepare, green, and low-cost substrate.20
Herein, we report a green, rapid, and cost-effective method to produce flexible, free-standing, and highly conductive SC electrodes made of GrP decorated with MnO2 nanoflowers for enhanced charge storage. GrP was prepared via electrochemical exfoliation of graphite sheets, which were then selfassembled using vacuum filtration. MnO2 nanoflowers were electrochemically deposited on GrP. The amount of MnO2 nanoflowers used was optimized by varying the number of electrodeposition cycles (1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 15, and 20). The electrode material obtained after 10 cycles of MnO2 deposition on GrP (GrP/10-MnO2, which is the optimal composition) exhibited high specific capacitance (Cs) with excellent capacitance retention. Then, a flexible solid-state asymmetric supercapacitor (SASc) device was assembled using GrP/10MnO2 and GrP as positive and negative electrode, respectively. The fabricated SASc device exhibited high areal capacitance of 76.8 mF cm−2 and long-term cycling stability of 82.2% after 5000 consecutive galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) cycles, and it delivered a high energy density of 6.14 mWh· cm−2 with a power density of 36 mW·cm−2.
■ MATERIALS AND METHODS Materials. Graphite sheets were obtained from Graphitestore, Inc. (U.S.A.). Manganese(II) acetate (Mn(CH3COO)2) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, U.S.A.). Sulfuric acid (H2SO4) was acquired from Acros chemicals (NJ, U.S.A.). Sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) was obtained from Fisher Chemicals (Fair Lawn, NJ, U.S.A.). Deionized (DI) water (18 MΩ·cm) was used in all experiments. Preparation of GrP and GrP/x-MnO2 Electrodes. GrP was fabricated as detailed in our previous report.20 Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrates were attached to the as-synthesized GrP using two-sided carbon tape and a copper foil with an alligator clip for good electrical contact as shown Scheme 1. Then, MnO2 was deposited onto the GrP electrodes potentiodynamically through CV cycles with a potential sweeping from 0.0 to 1.4 V at 50 mV·s−1 for different electrodeposition cycles (1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 15, and 20) in a solution containing 50 mM Mn(CH3COO)2 and 100 mM Na2SO4 using platinum (Pt) wire, Ag/AgCl (1 M KCl), and GrP as counter,
reference, and working electrode, respectively. After the deposition of MnO2, the electrodes were thoroughly washed with 5% HCl and DI water, followed by air drying at 60 °C for 30 min. The electrodes were labeled as GrP/x-MnO2 where x is the number of MnO2 deposition cycles used in the electrode preparation. The amount of MnO2 deposited on 0.2 mg of GrP ranged from 0 to 0.19 mg (Table S1).
Electrochemical Measurements. An electrochemical workstation (CH-660D, CH Instruments Inc., Austin, TX, U.S.A.) was used for the electrochemical analysis. A three-electrode configuration with Ag/AgCl (1 M KCl), Pt wire, and GrP/x-MnO2 as reference, counter, and working electrode, respectively, was used for the analysis of as-prepared electrodes. GCD and cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were performed in 50 mM Na2SO4 as electrolyte at room temperature. The electrodes were also characterized by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) using 0.1 M KCl with 5 mM ferrocyanide/ ferricyanide ([Fe(CN)6]
3−/4−) over 0.1 Hz to 100 kHz frequency range at open circuit potential. First, CV and GCD cycles were always discarded.
■ RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Recently, our group reported a novel synthesis method for GrP, which possesses low sheet resistance, high thermal and mechanical stability, and high capacitance compared with other reported flexible and free-standing 3D graphene network structures.20 Exfoliated graphene sheets, which form GrP by self-assembly, were further characterized by AFM. The height profile across the graphene sheet (Figure S1) reveals that it is <5 nm in thickness. A past AFM measurement reported the thickness of a graphene sheet as 1.5 ± 0.5 nm.28 Although a layer carbon atom is only 0.34 nm thick, a layer of graphene is thicker because of the electrostatic force between the graphene layer and the cantilever as well as the surface contaminations such as water and other surfactant molecules.28 Taking these factors into account, we conclude that the graphene sheets we exfoliated can contain one, two, or few layers of graphene. Electrodeposition of MnO2 onto the GrP was potentiodynamically done through CV cycles. As an example, electrodeposition process for GrP/10-MnO2 was investigated. CVs of GrP/10-MnO2 exhibited two anodic peaks at 0.8 and 1.1 V during the first anodic scan (Figure S1), which correspond to irreversible reaction of Mn2+. As the number of cycles increased, the anodic peak current (1.1 V) and cathodic peak current (0.42 V) increased because of the electro-oxidation of Mn2+, which confirms the successful deposition of MnO2 on the GrP as expressed in eqs 1−3:29−31
Scheme 1. Fabrication of GrP/x-MnO2 Electrode Using GrP via Electrochemical Deposition
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00797 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
B
→ ++ + −Mn Mn e2 3 (1)
+ → ++ +Mn 2H O MnOOH 3H3 2 (2)
→ + ++ −MnOOH MnO H e2 (3)
To investigate the interactions between GrP and MnO2, FTIR and Raman spectra of GrP and GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes were obtained. In the FT-IR spectra (Figure S3a), OH stretch (∼3430 cm−1), O−CO stretch (2326 cm−1), CO stretch (1725 cm−1), and CC stretch (1642 cm−1) peaks were observed. After deposition of MnO2 on GrP, the peak at 740 cm−1 increased because of Mn−O vibration.32 The Raman spectra (Figure S3b) of GrP and GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes show a decrease in intensities of D band at 1343 cm−1, G band at 1588 cm−1, and 2D band at 2710 cm−1 as the MnO2 deposition cycles increased.20 In contrast, the peak intensity at 643 cm−1 increased with the number of MnO2 deposition, which is an indication of the MnO2 formation on GrP.
13 Then, the GrP/10MnO2 were further analyzed with XPS. In Figure 1a, the widerange XPS spectra shows the peaks of C 1s, O 1s, and Mn (2p3/2, 2p1/2, 3p, 3s) for GrP/10-MnO2, illustrating the successful construction of MnO2 on the GrP surface. The broad Mn 2p1/2 (653.8 eV) and 2p3/2 (642.0 eV) peaks in Figure 1b is because of the overlap of Mn3+ and Mn4+ ions. Mn 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 peaks deconvoluted into two peaks 641.1 (Mn3+), 642.4 (Mn4+) eV using the XPS best peak fitting with Gaussian modes. The relative percent of Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio was calculated by peak area ratios, which was estimated to be about 34% on the GrP/10-MnO2 electrode surface. Additionally, 11.8
eV separation between Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 is in good agreement with published reports.13,33 The high-resolution O 1s spectrum (Figure 1c) shows peaks at 529.7 and 531.6 eV, which are attributed to Mn−O−Mn, and Mn−O−H bonding, respectively.34 The Mn−O−Mn/Mn−O−H ratio was also calculated by using peak area ratios and was found to be 1.72. This finding suggests that Mn primarily exists in the oxide form (MnO2) at the GrP/10-MnO2 electrode surface. The highresolution C 1s spectrum of GrP/10-MnO2 is shown in Figure 1d. Unlike the C 1s spectrum of GrP (Figure S4), peaks of oxidized carbon species (C−O and O−CO) were relatively weak. Figure S5 shows the XRD diffraction patterns for GrP and GrP/10-MnO2. A diffraction peak at around 25° was indexed to (002) plane reflection of graphene-based materials.35 The GrP/ 10-MnO2 showed sharp diffraction peaks at 22.4°, 34.6°, 36.9°, 38.2°, 42.49°, 56.4°, and 66.4°, which could be indexed to the characteristic peaks (120), (031), (131), (230), (300), (160), and (421) plane reflections of γ-MnO2 (JCPDS no. 14-0644), respectively.11 Beside to the γ-MnO2 peaks, the weak peaks located at ∼26°, 33.9°, 37.3°, 51.6°, 55.6°, and 61.9° observed because of (11−1), (020), (200), (12−1), (022), (22−2), and (131) plane reflections of MnOOH (JPSDS no. 41-1379), respectively.36 Both γ-MnO2 and MnOOH data are wellmatched with those reported in the literature. The presence of (002) plane reflection of graphene in the XRD spectra of the GrP/10-MnO2 electrode suggests the successful electrodeposition of highly crystalline γ-MnO2 and MnOOH on the GrP.
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00797 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
C
The surface morphology for GrP and GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes were analyzed with FE-SEM. The results show an interconnected 3D porous structure with a typical rippled and crumpled morphology of GrP, which is favorable for loading active materials (Figure 2a,b). After deposition of MnO2, we observe flower-like morphology with nanostructured petalshaped nanosheet agglomerates (Figure 2c−p), in which the size and number of MnO2 nanoflowers are proportional to the number of electrodeposition cycles. The individual size for MnO2 nanoflowers on the GrP were further analyzed by AFM. 2D and 3D views of GrP/7-MnO2 reveal a uniform coating of MnO2 nanoflowers onto GrP (Figures S6a and S6b). The height profile indicates that the size of individual MnO2 nanoparticles range from 150 to 200 nm and their heights range from 20 to 24 nm (Figures S6c and S6d). CV curves for GrP and GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes at scan rates from 1 to 30 mV·s−1 are rectangle-like in shape (Figure S7). It is
important to note that the CV curves do not show any significant redox peak toward 0 V vs Ag/AgCl, even under low scan rates. This is attributed to the diffusion-limited redox reactions (faradic) (e.g., reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+) which is slower than nondiffusion limited double layer charging process (nonfaradic).37 To compare their electrochemical performance, CV curves for all the electrodes were studied at a scan rate of 5 mV·s−1 (Figure 3a). The CV curve of GrP/10-MnO2 electrode was rectangular-shaped and enclosed the largest area, which is an indication of the best capacitive performance among all the prepared electrodes. Then, GrP/10-MnO2 electrode was investigated at various scan rates from 1 to 30 mV·s−1 (Figure 3b). The symmetrical and horizontal CV curves indicate an ideal capacitive behavior of supercapacitors. The CS (F·g
−1) of both GrP and GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes were calculated using their CV data by the following eq 4:
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00797 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX

(4)
where m (g) is the mass of loaded active electrode materials, v (V s−1) is the scan rate, and (Va − Vc) (V) is the potential window.38 The results showed that CS values increase with decreasing scan rates (Figure 3c) and with MnO2 deposition up to 10 cycles. The decrease in CS past 10 cycles of MnO2 deposition is attributed to the weak conductivity associated with the abundance of MnO2 electrodeposition on GrP.
Additionally, GrP capacitance contribution (CC) in the GrP/ x-MnO2 electrodes are given in the inset in Figure S8. At the lower deposition cycles, CC is very high, and the CC decreases while the number of deposition cycles increases. The CC of GrP is as low as 18% for the GrP/10-MnO2 electrode. The galvanostatic charge−discharge (GCD) curves, obtained in 50 mM Na2SO4 with the potential range of 0.0−1.0 V at the scan rate of 0.5 A·g−1, were studied to further analyzed the electrochemical properties of the as-synthesized GrP and GrP/ x-MnO2 electrodes (Figure 3e). The GrP/10-MnO2 electrode exhibited longer charge/discharge time compared with GrP and
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00797 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
E
other electrodes, and this result agreed well with CV results. The GCD curves at current densities of 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, and 4.0 A· g−1 were obtained for GrP/10-MnO2. As seen in Figure 3f, the charge−discharge curves are like equilateral triangles, indicating high reversibility during the GCD process with a fast I−V response. The energy density (E, W·h·kg−1) and power density (P, W·kg−1) of GrP/10-MnO2 are calculated on the basis of the GCD curves using eq 5:
= = *ΔP E t I V m (5)
where I (A) is the applied current, ΔV (V) is the potential window, t (h) is the discharge time, and m (kg) is the mass of the active materials. GrP/10-MnO2 exhibited excellent power density up to 3.72 kW·kg−1 at 4 A·g−1 and a high energy density up to 28.9 W·h·kg−1 at 0.25 A·g−1 The GrP/10-MnO2 electrode was also analyzed for its electrochemical stability using GCD for 5000 cycles at a current density of 4 A·g−1. The GrP/10-MnO2 electrode retained 85.4% of the capacitance after 5000 consecutive cycles (Figure 3g). The morphology of MnO2 on the surface GrP/10-MnO2, examined after 5000 consecutive cycles via SEM, shows no significant change (Figure S9). Moreover, Table 1 shows the capacitance behavior of GrP/10MnO2 electrode which is comparable to graphene−MnO2based composite systems.12,13,15,34,39,40
The electrochemical properties of GrP and GrP/10-MnO2 were also studied with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) by using the redox couple Fe(CN)4 4−/Fe(CN)6 3− as the electrolyte, and Figure 3h shows the Nyquist plots of GrP and GrP/10-MnO2. The redox couple Fe(CN)4 4−/Fe(CN)6 3− plays an important role in EIS, due to its electrochemical oxidation product (ferricyanide) and its inert property, namely less interaction between GrP-MnO2 and Fe
3+/Fe2+.41 Herein, we adopted it as electrolyte in EIS experiment. In the highfrequency region, the x-intercept is for the combined resistance (Rs = ∼ 15 Ω) containing contact and electrolyte resistance. The charge transfer resistance (Rct) is proportional to the diameter of the semicircular arcs.19 A bigger diameter arc indicates a larger Rct. The values of Rct for GrP and GrP/10-
MnO2 were approximately 2.1 and 9.8 Ω, respectively. The increase in the Rct value after deposition of MnO2 nanoflowers is due to the relatively poor electrical conductivity of MnO2. In the low-frequency region, the vertical shape suggests better capacitance performance for GrP and GrP/10-MnO2 electrodes. For portable and flexible electronics, flexible solid-state supercapacitor (SASc) devices are highly desirable. Therefore, an asymmetric SASc device was assembled using GrP/10MnO2 and GrP as positive and negative electrode, respectively, as illustrated in panels a and b of Figures 4. The CV curves of the SASc device at different potential windows up to 1.6 V was performed at a scan rate of 5 mV·s−1. The results show that the SASc device can be performed at a potential window of 1.2 V without the appearance of a polarized phenomenon. In Figure 4d, GCD curves are very symmetrical up to 1.0 V. On the basis of the analysis results of GCD and CV curves in Figures 4c,d, the SASc device was further tested at a potential window from 0.0 to 1.0 V with CV and GCD at different scan rates and current densities, respectively. CV cycles of the flexible SASc device at various scan rates are shaped rectangular-like (Figure 4e), implying a good rate capability, and the GCD curves at various current densities in Figure 4f show a triangle-like shape, indicating the ideal capacitive characteristics of the SASc device. The areal capacitance (CA, F·cm
−2) of SASc are calculated from GCD measurements based on eq 6:
= Δ
C It S V 2 A (6)
where I is the applied current (A), t is the discharge time (s), S is the active area of a single electrode (cm2), and ΔV is the potential window (V).42 The CA was the highest (76.8 mF· cm−2) at a current density of 0.05 mA·cm−2 and decreased with increasing current density (Figure 4g). The important parameters for SASc devices are the high-power (P, W·cm−2) and energy densities (E, W h·cm−2). The energy density (E, W h·cm−2) and power density (P, W·cm−2) of the SASc are calculated on the basis of eq 7 and eq 8, respectively:
= ΔE C V1 8 ( )A 2
(7)
=P E t (8)
where t (h) is the discharge time, CA is the areal capacitance, andΔV (V) is the potential window, excluding IR drop. For our flexible SASc device, the highest values of E = 6.14 mWh·cm−2 (at P = 36 mW·cm−2) and P = 50 mW·cm−2 (at E = 0.026 mWh·cm−2) were obtained. High capacitance retention is an essential parameter for SASc devices. The capacitance retention performance of the SASc was tested with 5000 consecutive GCD cycles at 50 mA cm−2 and revealed a retention of over 82% (Figure 4h). Compared with the results of previously reported graphene and MnO2 based SASc devices (Table 2), our as-assembled SASc device shows high areal capacitance, excellent energy and power densities, and acceptable capacitance retention.43−49 Two SASc devices were connected in series to show its practical application as a power source. After they were charged for 15 s at 3.5 V, the devices powered a red LED (Figure S10). Flexibility is of significant importance for portable and wearable energy-storage devices. Figure 4i shows GCD measurements of our flexible SASc device at 10 mA·cm−2.
work aGMCP: graphene/MnO2 composite papers, RGO/MnO2−CNTs: reduced graphene oxide (RGO)/birnessite-type MnO2 nanoarchitectures, FRGO-p-MnO2: poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA)/RGO/MnO2 nanosheets, HRG/MnO2: hydrothermally reduced graphene/MnO2, Gr-MnO2: graphene/MnO2, MnC-G: MnO2-coated carbon nanotubes/reduced graphene oxide composite, MnO2−CNT−graphene−Ni: carbon nanotube−graphene hybrids coated Ni foam with MnO2 immobilization.
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00797 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
F
When tested at bending angles of 0°, 90°, and 180°, the shape of the curves and discharge time remained almost unchanged. This excellent flexibility of the SASc device can be attributed to mechanically stable GrP and uniform deposition of MnO2 nanoflowers onto GrP.
■ CONCLUSIONS We report a green and rapid method to produce flexible, freestanding, and highly conductive supercapacitor electrodes made
of GrP decorated with MnO2 nanoflowers for enhanced charge storage. MnO2 nanoflowers were electrochemically deposited on GrP and optimized for the best capacitance performance. Then, a flexible SASc device was assembled, which showed not only an outstanding capacitance behavior but also an excellent capacitance retention performance. The performance of this flexible SASc device suggests the potential of the GrP/10MnO2 composite in the field of flexible energy-storage devices.
DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00797 ACS Appl. Nano Mater. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
G
■ ASSOCIATED CONTENT *S Supporting Information The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acsanm.9b00797.
Material characterization, mass loading of MnO2 for GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes, XPS spectra for GrP, AFM, FTIR and Raman spectra for GrP and GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes, XRD spectra of GrP and GrP/10-MnO2 electrodes, cyclic voltammetry data for GrP and GrP/xMnO2 electrodes, capacitance contribution (CC) of GrP in the GrP/x-MnO2 electrodes, the surface morphology of GrP/10-MnO2 after 5000 GCD cycles, and digital photograph of four SASc devices powering a red LED (PDF)
■ AUTHOR INFORMATION Corresponding Author *E-mail: guna@wisc.edu.

references.title: Manganese oxide micro-supercapacitors with ultra-high areal capacitance
author: S. P

metadata.abstractText: We recently reported a simple and costeffective green method to produce free-standing, flexible, and highly conductive electrochemically exfoliated graphene paper (GrP) for a supercapacitor application. To improve the capacitance behavior of GrP, manganese dioxide (MnO2) was electrochemically deposited on GrP with different number of MnO2 cycles. After the electrochemical deposition process, MnO2 nanoflowers were formed, which provide a fast transfer of electrolyte ions. After 10 cycles of electrodeposition, MnO2-coated GrP (GrP/10-MnO2, which is the optimal composition) exhibited an excellent capacitive performance with a high specific capacitance of 385.2 F·g−1 at 1 mV·s−1 in 0.1 M Na2SO4 electrolyte and outstanding capacitance retention after 5000 consecutive cycles. Taking advantage of both superior mechanical and capacitance behavior of GrP and GrP/10-MnO2 electrodes, a flexible solid-state asymmetric supercapacitor (SASc) device was assembled using GrP/10-MnO2 and GrP as positive and negative electrode, respectively. The fabricated SASc device exhibited not only high areal capacitances of 76.8 mF cm−2 at a current density of 0.05 mA cm−2 but also excellent cycling stability of 82.2% after 5000 consecutive galvanostatic charge/discharge cycles. This flexible supercapacitor can also deliver a high energy density of 6.14 mWh·cm−2 with a power density of 36 mW·cm−2. This research represents a new direction for exploring the potential of free-standing GrP and its nanocomposites in flexible energy-storage systems.
